result.name: Gut Monitoring Report

content.title: Traits Overview
content.description:
Your gut is home to millions of bacteria-some are helpful, and some can cause trouble. The helpful ones play essential roles like fighting off harmful germs, helping you digest food, and keeping your weight and energy balanced. When these good bacteria are present in high amounts, your body will likely stay healthy and strong. On the other hand, too many harmful bacteria can throw your gut off balance. 

This can lead to inflammation, digestive problems, lower immunity, and even increase the risk of conditions like obesity, diabetes, and heart disease. In short, the more good bacteria you have and the fewer bad ones, the better your chances of feeling well and staying healthy.

content.title: Bacterial Diversity
content.description:
This section will help you understand how many different species of bacteria are in your gut. 

Higher diversity = healthier gut.

content.title: Beneficial Bacteria
content.description: These are your gut's "good guys"-they support your mood, digestion, and immune system.

content.title: Metabolism
content.description:
Your gut microbes make powerful chemicals that help your body burn fat, balance blood sugar, and even boost your mood and sleep.

Some of these fight inflammation and support weight loss, while others can slow things down or raise disease risk. This report shows how your gut is affecting your metabolism and what you can do to improve it.

content.title: Food Tolerance
content.description: Digbi's Gut Biome report will help you learn to identify foods that might cause intolerances. You'll also learn how to improve side effects, like bloating and gassiness, caused by food intolerances.

content.title: Blood Sugar and Appetite
content.description:
Your gut bacteria help control how hungry you feel and how well your body handles sugar. They make special compounds that support hormones like GLP-1, which help you feel full and keep blood sugar steady. But some bacteria can also break these hormones down too fast. 

This report shows how your gut influences your cravings, energy, and overall metabolic health.

insight.heading: Food Insights
insight.content:
- Incorporate anti-inflammatory foods, such as leafy greens, and berries, to support a balanced gut environment.
 - Choose fiber-rich foods, like whole grains, legumes, and vegetables, to promote the production of short-chain fatty acids that aid GLP-1 release.
- Minimize processed foods, added sugars, and refined carbs that may disrupt gut health and hinder GLP-1 modulation.

insight.heading: Lifestyle Insights
insight.content:
- Engage in moderate exercise, such as walking or cycling, to stimulate GLP-1 production and support metabolic health.
- Practice stress-reducing activities like mindfulness or yoga, as stress can negatively impact gut health and hormone regulation.
- Good sleep supports gut function and helps maintain balanced GLP-1 levels, contributing to better blood sugar control and appetite management.

3. Here's how your sample compares to a cohort of healthy American individuals.

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine the potential of your gut microbes to produce acetate, we analyzed the abundance of 5 different bacterial genes involved in acetate synthesis. To learn more, see the following:

traits.what: Acetate is like a peacekeeper. It calms your gut, protects the lining, and helps keep your gut-brain connection strong.
traits.impact: Low acetate is linked to brain fog, inflammation, and poor mood. It's crucial for gut lining integrity and supporting brain energy.

insight.content:
Vegetables that contain anthocyanins, a pigment found in plants, can help increase Akkermansia levels.

3. Here's how your sample compares to a cohort of healthy American individuals.

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine the potential of your gut microbes to break down alcohol, we analyzed the abundance of 4 different bacterial genes involved in alcohol degradation. To learn more, see the following:

traits.what: Some bacteria help break down alcohol. But how well you do this varies.
traits.impact: Better breakdown = less hangover, less liver stress. Poor breakdown = higher risk of health issues from alcohol.

insight.content: Regardless of your results, Digbi Health does not recommend any level of alcohol consumption. Alcohol is inflammatory, obesogenic, and carcinogenic.

traits.riskDescription: The recent sample of your gut microbiome indicates that you have a moderate abundance of alcohol-degrading bacteria.

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine the potential of your gut microbes to break down Arginine, we analyzed the abundance of 4 different bacterial genes involved in Arginine degradation.

traits.what: Arginine is a nutrient your gut bacteria help break down. When they do this well, they create helpful signals that support energy and metabolism.
traits.impact: A gut that breaks down arginine well can help your body burn fat, keep blood sugar stable, and improve circulation. This process works best when arginine-rich foods are eaten with the right kind of fiber, which helps your gut microbes do their job better.
traits.riskDescription: The recent sample of your gut microbiome indicates that you have a low abundance of Arginine-degrading bacteria.

traits.name: Bacterial Diversity
tooltip: 1. This is your likelihood based on your gut microbiome.
2. This is your sample collection date.
3. Here's how your sample compares to a cohort of healthy American individuals.

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine your bacterial diversity, we measured the number of bacterial species and their abundance in your gut and compared them to a group of healthy Americans.

traits.what: Think of your gut like a rainforest. The more kinds of plants and animals (bacteria) it has, the better it can handle stress and stay balanced. A diverse microbiome means your gut is more resilient and supports everything from immunity to digestion.
traits.impact: Higher diversity = stronger immunity, better digestion, and less inflammation. Low diversity is linked to many chronic diseases and poor gut resilience.

insight.content:
Fermented foods can help improve bacterial diversity.

Check out the Digbi Food Guide to learn more about how to include them in your daily meals.

insightLinks.name: How to eat for a diverse microbiota

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine the potential of your gut microbes to produce hydrogen sulfide gas, we analyzed the abundance of 8 different bacterial genes involved in making hydrogen sulfide. To learn more, see the following:

traits.what: A little bit of this gas protects your gut lining. Too much, though, causes inflammation.
traits.impact: High levels are linked to digestive diseases. Healthy balance supports gut health and prevents leaky gut.

insight.content: The following foods help reduce the presence of hydrogen sulfide gas-producing bacteria::

insight.heading: Vegetables:
insight.content:
Group 1 -  celery, mushrooms, cucumbers, lettuce, bamboo shoots
Group  2 - bell peppers, egg plants, tomato, zucchini

insight.heading: Fruits:
insight.content:
Group 1 - blueberries
Group 2 - apple, melon, orange, peaches, pears, watermelon

insight.heading: Proteins:
insight.content:
Meat in moderation - consume animal proteins along with plant fibers
Fish - oysters, sardines, salmon
Dark meat - chicken, turkey

insight.heading: Nuts:
insight.content: Macadamia nuts

insight.heading: Herbs::
insight.content: Ginger

insight.heading: Probiotics::
insight.content: Kefir, kombucha, miso, natto, tempeh, and fermented vegetables

insight.heading: Beverages::
insight.content: Herbal tea

traits.name: Imidazole Propionate
tooltip: 1. This is your likelihood based on your gut microbiome.
2. This is your sample collection date.
3. Here's how your sample compares to a cohort of healthy American individuals.

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine the potential of your gut microbes to produce imidazole propionate, we analyzed the abundance of 2 different bacterial genes involved inmaking imidazole propionate. To learn more, see the following:

traits.what: This is a "troublemaker" molecule made by some gut bacteria that blocks insulin action.
traits.impact: Can lead to insulin resistance, prediabetes, and makes diabetes meds (like metformin) less effective.

insight.content: The following foods help reduce the presence of imidazole propionate-producing bacteria:

insight.heading: Magnesium rich foods:
insight.content:
Dark leafy vegetables
Mushrooms

insight.heading: Proteins:
insight.content:
Chicken
Turkey
Fish (mackerel, tuna, crab, mollusks)

insight.heading: Nuts & Seeds:
insight.content: Hemp seeds, pumpkin seeds, squash seeds, flax seeds, brazil nuts, sesame seeds, chia seeds, sunflower seeds, cashews, almonds, and pine nut

insight.heading: Restrict intake of:
insight.content: Cheese, eggs, milk, high carbohydrate foods, high saturated fats (red meat)

insightLinks.name: How Gut microbiota affects insulin response

tooltip: 1. This is your likelihood based on your gut microbiome.
2. This is your sample collection date.
3. Here's how your sample compares to a cohort of healthy American individuals.

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine the potential of your gut microbes to break down Lysine, we analyzed the abundance of 6 different bacterial genes involved in Lysine degradation.

traits.what: Lysine is an important building block your body needs. Your gut bacteria can turn it into fuel that helps your body stay active and balanced.
traits.impact: Breaking down lysine well helps your body use fat for energy and keeps inflammation down. The benefits are even stronger when your protein intake is combined with gut-friendly fiber based on your sensitivities.
traits.riskDescription: The recent sample of your gut microbiome indicates that you have a low abundance of Lysine-degrading bacteria.

tooltip: 1. This is your likelihood based on your gut microbiome.
2. This is your sample collection date.
3. Here's how your sample compares to a cohort of healthy American individuals.

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine the potential of your gut microbes to produce DPP4, we analyzed the abundance of one bacterial gene involved in DPP4 synthesis. To learn more, see the following:

traits.what: Some bacteria make an enzyme that "turns off" your fullness hormone (GLP-1) too early.
traits.impact: Too much DPP4 can make it harder to control appetite and blood sugar-especially if you have inflammation.

insight.content: The following foods can help support a healthy gut lining and may help prevent gut inflammation:

insight.heading: Vegetables
insight.content: Group 1 and Group 2

insight.heading: Other sources:
insight.content: Omega-3 rich foods, bone broth, fermented foods, polyphenol-rich foods, anti-inflammatory spices, healthy fats

insight.heading: Foods to Avoid:
insight.content: Processed foods, refined sugars, artificial sweeteners, gluten (if sensitive), excess caffeine and alcohol, and high-FODMAP foods (if sensitive)
Check out your 'Go-to Superfoods' list in your Personalized Wellness Report to see the best options for your unique body!

traits.name: Tryptophan Support
tooltip: 1. This is your likelihood based on your gut microbiome.
2. This is your sample collection date.
3. Here's how your sample compares to a cohort of healthy American individuals.

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine the potential of your gut microbes to produce tryptophan, we analyzed the abundance of 6 different bacterial genes involved in making tryptophan. To learn more, see the following:

traits.what: Tryptophan is the starter block for serotonin (the "feel-good" brain chemical) and melatonin (the sleep hormone).
traits.impact: Low tryptophan is linked to depression, poor sleep, and digestion issues.

insight.content: The following foods support the growth of tryptophan-producing bacteria in the gut:

insight.heading: Resistant Starches:
insight.content: Beans - white beans, kidney beans, pinto beans, or black beans. Remember to follow the cooking process outlined in the Food Guide.

insight.heading: Proteins:
insight.content:
Meat chicken, lean-cut beef, and pork
Fish
Eggs
Soy products - tofu, soy milk, edamame, soybeans, or tempeh

insight.heading: Nuts & Seeds:
insight.content: Pumpkin seeds, chia seeds, sesame seeds, flax seeds, walnuts, and hemp seeds

insight.heading: Probiotics:
insight.content: Yogurt, buttermilk, kefir, sauerkraut, kimchi, natto, cottage cheese, fermented pickles, tempeh, and miso

traits.riskDescription: The recent sample of your gut microbiome indicates that you have a low abundance of Tryptophan-producing bacteria.

traits.name: Tryptophan Breakdown
tooltip: 1. This is your likelihood based on your gut microbiome.
2. This is your sample collection date.
3. Here's how your sample compares to a cohort of healthy American individuals.

analysis.title: Gut biome analysis
analysis.text: To determine the potential of your gut microbes to break down Tryptophan, we analyzed the abundance of 1 bacterial gene involved in Tryptophan degradation.

traits.what: Tryptophan helps your brain and gut work together. When your gut microbes break it down, they send signals that support mood, sleep, and digestion.
traits.impact: If your gut processes tryptophan well, you may experience better emotional balance, sleep quality, and metabolism. These benefits are boosted when your meals include the right fiber for your digestive system.
traits.riskDescription: The recent sample of your gut microbiome indicates that you have a low abundance of Tryptophan-degrading bacteria.

The information on this report is for educational and informational use only.

The information is not intended to be used by the customer for any diagnostic purpose and is not a substitute for professional medical advice.

You should always seek the advice of your physician or other healthcare providers with any questions you may have regarding diagnosis, cure, treatment, mitigation, or prevention of any disease or other medical condition or impairment or the status of your health.
